document.title: Builder window

toc.envision_location: Eiffel ENViSioN!\Developing with Eiffel ENViSioN!\Adding a New Project\Advanced GUI Project Wizard\Interface Construction Page\Reference

document.paragraph:
The Builder window provides a view of the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects in your system, in which the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects may be manipulated.
This window may either be shown or hidden (default). To change between these two states, click
/images/eiffelbuild/icons/icon_builder_window_color.png on the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/10_general_interface_description/20_main_toolbars.xml main toolbar , or select Show/Hide builder window from the View menu.
/images/eiffelbuild/screenshots/builder_window.png
The content of this window is a representation of the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects you have defined in your project. Each
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object object is represented by the
/libraries/vision2/00_introduction.xml EiffelVision2 control matching its type. For example, an
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object object representing an EV_BUTTON will be displayed in here using an EV_BUTTON. As this view provides direct access to the objects (
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#pick_and_drop Pick any of the controls in this window), it enables you to build your interface within a view which provides rich visual feedback. Because this window is just a view of the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects , it will be always synchronized with the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/20_layout_constructor/index.xml layout constructor . This means you can
/tools/eiffelbuild/how_to_s/50_reparent_an_object/index.xml reparent objects , using the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#pick_and_drop pick and drop transport method, seamlessly between the two views.
2Visual Differences
Although the builder window attempts to show you the interface you are developing, it is not a completely accurate representation (Unlike the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/50_layout_window/index.xml display window ). The main difference is that all
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects representing descendents of EV_CONTAINER are parented in a frame. This was implemented so that you would be able to easily manipulate the containers.
Imagine that this was not the case, and each container
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object object was just represented by an
/libraries/vision2/00_introduction.xml EiffelVision2 object matching its type. Because these containers have no visible screen space when filled with children, manipulation of them would have been difficult, and the functionality of this view would be compromised.
In the screenshot above, you can see that there are two
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects representing containers in your project, an EV_VERTICAL_BOX, and an EV_HORIZONTAL_BOX (Excluding the EV_TITLED_WINDOW
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object object represented by this window).
The properties of the
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects in you system are always reflected in this window, with a few exceptions:
'user_can_resize', 'maximum_width', 'maximum_height' and 'title_string' are not reflected in this window.
'minimum_width' and `minimum_height' are not reflected in any of the controls representing
/tools/eiffelbuild/reference/02_notation.xml#object objects within this window.
See also
